column4: If they are usb or esata drives, you might try booting into Windows and "Safely Remove Hardware" than see if Ubuntu lists them.
Try System-->Administration--> Gparted and see if they are listed there.
You could always use Windows to copy all of the data from them and then, using a partitioning tool and reformat them to ext3 or ext4, CAUTION, reformatting will destroy ALL data on those drives.
What I can't figure is the "Unknown"?
Can't fathom why Nautilus doesn't see them.
In Nautilus, did you click "view" then "side pane"?
Only other thing: open a terminal and type sudo fdisk -l     That's a lower case L...
If they also do not show up in "Places", than I'm lost...Sorry
Sorry...:-( Maybe a little later, ask again here; the guys you're lookin' for is dr_Willis or ActionParsnip.
Did you install ubuntu from within the Windows environment?
